Publisher's Notice.

Subscription price: 50 cents per annum, by mail in advance; single copies one cent.

The rates for our advertising space by columns are as follows:

One Column: $1.00 per month.
Half Column: $0.50 per month.
Quarter-column: $0.25 per month.
Two-Column: $1.50 per month.
Business card size: $0.10 per month.

The above rates do not apply to display advertisements, entertainments, tender meetings, or any other special announcements. Rates may be increased at any time without additional notice. Yearly advertisements will be charged at the rate of $1.00 per month.

Business cards, 50 cents for first twenty, 40 cents for each additional twenty.

The publishers reserve the right to reject any advertisements of questionable or objectionable character.

Tenders.

SEALED TENDERS addressed to the City Chamberlain Wesley Municipality and enclosed in sealed envelopes for Tender Box No. 1, will be received up till Friday, Feb. 26th.

Building a Bridge on the Qu'Appelle.

Near W.P.O. Order's farm, Post Office and road crossing can be seen at Honesty Creek's, who has kindly offered his land. Tenders to be opened on Saturday, 27th.

By the Board of HUNTLEY-CAMPBELL, Post Office Bridge Committee.

Mail Contract.

SEALED TENDERS addressed to the Postmaster General will be received at the Post Office, Qu'Appelle, until Tuesday, February 26th, 1886.

Friday, Feb. 26th.

Auction Sale of Valuable Freehold Property.

To Messrs. Smith & Co., in the Northeast Territories and in Manitoba West of the First Principal Meridian.

Under and by virtue of a power of sale contained in a certain mortgage which was executed by Mr. Smith & Co., there will be sold by Public Auction, by Fred. J. Suther, Auctioneer, at the Post Office, Qu'Appelle Station, on the 27th day of February, 1886, all the North West Territories of Canada, on the 27th day of February, 1886.

Notice.

The meeting advertised to take place on the 9th instant, was duly held and proceedings were passed on the following resolutions:

Resolved, That the Agricultural Society of the Town of Qu'Appelle, be called "The South Qu'Appelle Agricultural Association." The fee for members shall be one dollar, payable in advance.

The meeting will be held at the present year, President, W. A. Holbrook; 1st Vice-President, T. Wrigley; 2nd Vice-President, H. F. Smith; Secretary, L. M. Smith; Treasurer, L. N. Fisher; Directors, J. C. Taylor, J. G. Craig, J. K. Bates, R. B. Brown and R. Skinner.

The officers will be elected at the annual meeting on Saturday the 15th inst., at 1 o'clock p.m.

Rapid City Ripples.

Mr. D. A. Hopper has returned from Rapid City.

Public Notice.

Ellisboro Post Office.

At Ellisboro post office some beautiful hyacinths in full bloom may be seen, brought there by Mr. E. Johnson, a highly skilled gardener as some people imagine.

Ellisboro.

Qu'Appelle Progress.
Holy Catholic Church.

Its Continuity in England

A Lecture Delivered by the Bishop of Tybetty, Jan. 24.

The subject upon which I am about to speak today is “The continuity of the Church in England.” I purposely say ‘the church’, because, speaking generally, if we desire to make known our church we must go back to a time long before they were strictly speaking ‘English or Anglicans’, but rather by that word we mean the state of what we now know as Denmark. Our mother country had been in our native land for a whole century before Hogiest landed at Bristol in 679 A.D., and about 949. The Christian church had been in the country at the very last three centuries before Edwin, King of Mercia, became its first bishop. The bishops of the British church were consecrated at the Council of Arles in 313 A.D., showing that even then existed the church in Britain in a distinctly organized form. But it would be impossible in the mere space of an hour to give even by name the earliest names in the history of the church extending over more than fifteen centuries, if we were free from the necessity of taking in all those whose beliefs have been very varied subjects of interest in connection with it. In these few centuries of English church history there may be traced not only the decay of the Romanized state, but also the growth of national influences; and, indeed, though there was no such thing as a nationality, yet as a race there was definitely an English character in the formation of the church, and their common consciousness of belonging to the same people was seen in the unity of their opinions. It must be remembered that at first there was a great deal of misunderstanding between their Mercian and Saxon families of the most ancient lingoistic varieties which have been preserved from the primitive stage of our civilization. This is my body, this is my blood. The cardinal error of the primitive Christians of Spain had been accurately to define doctrines, that he early church in times will not see the lingoistic variations which exist in the primitive churches.

We may go back farther still in the history of the church and see that its continuity was maintained throughout the centuries of Roman occupation. The Romano-British church continued after the fall of Rome. This is made plain by the preservation of many inscriptions, coins, and other relics connected with the primitive Christians of that period. These primitive Christians of the seventh and eighth centuries are not merely the ancestors of the later Anglo-Saxon church, but are quite different in their religious ideas and traditions. The Anglo-Saxons were a warrior race, and their religious ideas were influenced by their military life. They were also a kind of savage people, and their religious ideas were influenced by the customs and superstitions of the savage. The Roman influence was weak and fading, and the Anglo-Saxon church was able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence.

We must not forget that the Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence. The Roman influence was strong, but the Anglo-Saxon church was not able to maintain its own independence.

We see an entirely new order of service was adopted by the later imitators, for which there can be no excuse whatever. No one who speaks foreign languages can be made to believe that that which has ever been considered the highest act of prayer among the primitive Christians of the East, would have been considered simply as a change from the primitive, when made by the prayers of men of good intention. Now let us turn our attention to the particular matters of doctrine. For we must note that, while the faith of the church remains unaltered, the form of its church order is far from uniform throughout all its generations. We must therefore examine the various orders of service that have been current in the church. It is impossible to enumerate them all, but we may mention the following:—

1. The Reformation Liturgy.

2. The Church's Liturgy.

3. The Liturgy of the Primitive Church.

4. The Liturgy of the Anglo-Saxon Church.

5. The Liturgy of the Roman Church.

As these orders of service are very frequently mistaken for matters of faith, and often the wars of the church are merely struggles between different parties, so the church order is frequently the subject of controversy. The church order should be regarded as a part of the doctrine of the church. It is impossible to say how much importance should be attached to it, but we must remember that it is the substance of our faith that is concerned. We must also keep in mind the fact that the church order is not the same in all countries, although the substance of our faith is the same everywhere.
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of One Dollar, with the object of enforcing advance payment. We can make no profit by publishing a paper at that price when we know that every paper going out is paid for, than if we took the chances of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides we thus at once secure a large circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1887.

GRAND COLONIAL EXHIBITION
In London, England, 1858.
FOURTY-FOUR THOUSAND FEET RESERVED FOR CANADA.
First Royal Exhibition Commission—Sir W. Ewart.
The Colonial and Indian Exhibition to be held in London, England, commencing May 1st, 1858, is intended to be a great national event, and will be an object to mark an epoch in the relations of Great Britain and her Colonies, and of each other.
It will give becoming significance to the great Royal Commission as formed by Her Majesty Queen Victoria, and will be the first time since 1857, and the Royal Highnesses will attend it. Mr. Joseph Molyneux, President of His Majesty's Government, has promised 5,000 square feet which will be devoted to the Dominion of Canada. The Exhibition is to be purely Colonial and Indian, and no competition from the outside world will be permitted, the object being to exhibit the best productions of the Colonies.
The greatest opportunity ever offered to Canada is thus afforded to show the fine products of her soil and her resources. The progress she has made in manufactures, in literature, and the arts, is now being appreciated throughout the world. The manufacturers, artists, and inventors in Canada are anxious to display their vast resources in this great exhibition, and are doing so with much zeal, and also in Europe.
The members of the various classes are invited to come forward and visit the exhibition, as it will be a great source of pride and honour to Canada in her true place as a nation. We should not fail to see it, and establish her proper position before the world. Every farmer, every producer, and every citizen should visit it, as it is evident that Canada is having already demonstrated that she can produce anything she chooses to offer.
By order,
JOHN LOWE,
Sec'y. of the Dept. of Agriculture.
Ontario, Sept. 18th, 1858.

CONSUMPTION CURED.
An old physician, retired from practice,
having had placed in his hands by an East Indian missionary the formula which had
worked so well in India, and prevent-
ing cure of Consumption, Bronchitis, Ca-
stanea, rheumatism, consumed limbs,
toothache, also a positive and radical cure for
Nervous debility and all Servant Complaints,
also for the consumption of children and
widows in thorns of cases, has felt it his
duty to bring it kindness in his suffering fol-
lowers. As every case cannot be handled to
relieve human suffering I will send free
of charge, a booklet on the subject, my
name in German, French and English, the ful-
filling our preparations for sending and using. Sent by
mail by adding 5 cents postage, running this paper.
W. A. STEINER (Poveshelle, Ont.).

Engagements in England.
English girls marry before many have
the opportunity to visit that country at
the age of thirty. A marriage in England is
not considered marriage; "a young man of
about twenty-five who becomes engaged to a lady of say 18, and the lady remain
thus engaged for three or even five
years. During the engagement the
girl lives with the girl's parents, she has
one life without any of its troubles, and she is under the constant control of
her best to make the engagement last
as long as possible. The parents may
manufacture more love for her to habitual
use and make the months of delay seem
no worse. The cultivated cottage where the
prostitute sojourns is cool and homely
and cool. On the day she leaves she
does not expect to be there again. So
there is nothing but work and
business that keeps the poor woman
in England for years. She does not
pretend to be lonely because she
knows business keeps her occupied.
Her husband's business is done for her. She
does nothing for herself except work.
When her husband dies an English
woman loses her husband and becomes a
widow. If she is unfortunate she
becomes a governess, housekeeper, or a
maid servant. When she is good
she gets a nice position as a governess
or a housekeeper, but when she is
glutton, she gets her husband's place
with the same wages and the same
job. When she becomes a
widow she gets no pension but her hus-
band's estate goes to others than the
widow. She must take care of
herself and her child. If she chooses
to send them away she must choose
the best school for the child.

NOTICE.
Notice is hereby given that an application will be made before
the North West Central Rail-
way Company, the Canadian Pacific
Railway Company, the Ottawa
Lachine Railroad Company, the
Government of Canada, for an Act to incorporate the "North West Central Railway Co., Ltd.," having such
power and authority as a private railway
company, to build a railroad in the
Province of Ontario and the Province
of Quebec, and to sell and dispose of
all property in case of insolvency,
for such purpose.
T. J. McLELLAN, Esq.,
President of the N.W.C.R.G.,
Toronto, Oct. 26th, 1883.

**Home & Gossip**

**Qu'Appelle**

- Sunday is St. Valentine's day.
- See McMillan Bros. advertisement.
- Council met Saturday last; minutes next week.

Advertisement at Tur Jackson's office is the printing business.

- Bring your No. 1 hard wheat to Qu'Appelle and get 75 cents per bushel for it.

- The weather past week has been very mild. The snow is nearly all gone and the sledding is bad.

In His Honor, the Lieutenant-Governor, has appointed Mr. W S Redpath an inspector of marriage licences for the North-West provinces.

- Messrs. McMillan Bros. are determined to beat Qu'Appelle in their "No. 2 Hard Tobacco" stakes set up for the best wheel maker in the Northwest. They are even giving better than Winningham made "good old tobacco".

- Winnifred Watson, Mfg. Co., A. Holiday, Inc., Rogers, Winnipeg, H. L. Elliott, Inc., Jas. J. Hurd, Jap. Gibbon. Bud Appleyard advertised at the Elahad House this week.

- On Saturday last Pastors Van duft and Pierre Vachal, two well known French Preachers from France, came here by way of Edmonton. They had been under a long sentence at a montain air, but were paroled and released.

- The Carnaval

Masters Johnson, Mrs. Garrett, Place, Henry, Braden and several others attended Carnaval this season last Saturday evening and had made the most of the occasion. Everybody enjoyed themselves. A new feature was the appearance among the fiddlers, notably among those following:

- Masters, Snowshoe,
- Mrs. Boadie, Snowshoe.
- Mr. R. S. Alexander, King of the event.
- Mr. S. Alexander, Queen of lovers.
- Masters, Edwap, 2nd, The Queen of cunning.
- Mr. V. Lucas, Danny Jim, The King of residence.
- Mrs. Less, La Princesse de Reguneet, The Queen of residence.
- Messrs. Duclos, Olimick, Minervin & Co., The Riders.
- Messrs. Bob Brown, cowboy or Rossoro, Shine.

In Our Honor, William, Wilson, the delegation appeared by the afternoon train and on their way back to Ottawa had visited the sites of the former polemicists of the Ottawa district.

- We this week gives the first half of the lecture before members of the Englic Church. Tuesday at 4 p.m. at the Bishop of Qu'Appelle, he will start the second half of his lecture on the Catholic Church.

On Saturday morning last the Institutes of Faith and Charity signs of being too wet fell, and when passing the Puooshiosk office were greeted by rain again which seemed to be comfortable for the passengers. The town hall on Saturday near the Methodist church, a sleigh was speaking out loud on the sidewalks and lounging. The horses ran into a blind spot by the and their run was prematurely ended vice. No damage was done.

**Mr. Lewis G. Irvine gave the following for publication. — Wednesday Mr. Irvine having experienced a loss by having smothered what the last season park find the fir trees a Montgomery goddess. Any who may be there used again lose and indelible 11b. of sulphate of copper to each bushel of grain, and dip your seed grain in the pickle the night before sowing. One pound of the solution is sufficient for four bushels of wheat.

At Qu'Appelle, morning, a Council of the Royal Temple of Holy Wisdom was organized by the following members: Mr. T. Lucas, Mrs. Lewis, Mrs. G. Nimזמ, Vice-President Mrs. Oliver, M. H. Bantam, Secretary Mrs. Oliver, Mr. Lamar. All members are requested to attend and meet this week another meeting at the Royal Temple of Holy Wisdom.

It is now considered essential for every student of theology to make the acquaintance of the Catholic Church, by reading the book of its Mysteries, and learning the name of its Founder, the Holy Roman Catholic Church.

THE CRADLE.

On Sep. 19, Tp. 18, R. 16, on the 28th inst. Mrs. John Ewing, of this village, gave birth to a child.
